summary: This is a sealed application and order from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, seeking and obtaining court permission to unseal discovery materials from the settled civil case 'Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al.' for use in a then-secret federal grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for sex trafficking of minors. The document reveals the government's covert effort to obtain evidence from a private law firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP, which was bound by a protective order.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney whose office is making the application to unseal discovery materials for a grand jury investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named defendant in the civil case 'Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al.' and the subject of the federal grand jury investigation for sex trafficking of minors.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named defendant in the civil case 'Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al.', implicated in the conspiracy to traffic minors.

persons.name: Lesley Groff
persons.context: Named defendant in the civil case 'Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al.'.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Attorney at Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP who represented the plaintiff (Jane Doe 43) in the civil case; her litigation files are believed to contain information relevant to the criminal investigation.

persons.name: Sarah Netburn
persons.context: The judge who signed the order granting the government's application to unseal the discovery materials.

connections.description: Co-defendants in the civil lawsuit, alleged to have participated in a conspiracy to traffic minors for commercial sex acts.
Co-defendants in the same civil lawsuit, suggesting a legal and potentially operational association.
McCawley, as an attorney for Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP, represented the plaintiff Jane Doe 43 in the civil case against Epstein and others.
Berman's office (the USAO-SDNY) was conducting a grand jury investigation into Epstein for federal sex trafficking crimes.

events.title: Civil Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Plaintiff Jane Doe 43 files a civil action against Jeffrey Epstein, Ghislaine Maxwell, and Lesley Groff, alleging a conspiracy to traffic minors for commercial sex acts.

events.title: Protective Order Issued
events.description: The court issues a protective order in the civil case, restricting disclosure of discovery materials marked 'CONFIDENTIAL'.

events.title: Civil Case Settled and Dismissed
events.description: The parties enter into a settlement agreement and voluntarily dismiss the civil action 'Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al.'.

events.title: Government Seeks to Unseal Discovery
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney files a sealed affirmation applying for an order to unseal discovery materials from the settled civil case for use in an ongoing grand jury investigation.

events.title: Court Orders Unsealing for Grand Jury
events.description: Magistrate Judge Sarah Netburn grants the government's application, ordering Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP to provide the sealed discovery materials to the government for the grand jury investigation.

keyFacts: In February 2019, the U.S. Attorney's Office was conducting a secret federal grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for sex trafficking of minors (Sections 1591, 1594(c), and 2422(b) of Title 18).

The government sought and obtained a court order to bypass a protective order from a settled civil case (Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein) to obtain discovery materials held by the plaintiff's law firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP.

The existence and scope of this criminal investigation in the Southern District of New York was not publicly known at the time, and the application was filed under seal to prevent targets from being alerted.
The civil case, which alleged a conspiracy to traffic minors, was filed in January 2017 and settled in December 2018, with a protective order issued in November 2018.

The document includes the full text of the protective order, which defines 'CONFIDENTIAL' information to include details about sexual activity, medical conditions, and personal identifying information.
